awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Nanostructured 3D Catalytic Coatings for High-Efficiency Pollution Control and Air Purification
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is addressing the growing societal need for indoor air purification, as indoor air quality (IAQ) directly affects human health, productivity, cognitive function, and quality-of-life. Awareness of the long-term consequences of poor IAQ has recently witnessed an increase due to research results, improvements in monitoring and sensing technology, public awareness campaigns by organizations such as the American Lung Association, World Health Organization, and Environmental Protection Agency, and, most recently, the COVID-19 pandemic. Finding sustainable, economical, and effective solutions to the problem of poor IAQ will greatly benefit public health and wellbeing and will help curtail the spread of pathogens, minimizing the need for social distancing.  This project will develop a new system air purification, addressing viruses, harmful chemicals, odors, and ultrafine particulates.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project aims to scale up the production methodology and coating process of novel catalytic materials. The materials are 3D nanostructured porous powders that are designed at multiple length scales to achieve enhanced catalytic activity, stability, and longevity, while reducing costs and utilizing raw materials in an environmentally responsible manner. The system uses a synthetic approach based on self-organization of nanoscale building blocks and wet chemistry tools in order to assemble finely structured coatings for integration in air-purification units. This project focuses on expanding it to production scale, wherein achieving control over the composition, structure, porosity, and placement of nanoparticles on a production scale is challenging.  The materials platform development will include adaptation to high-throughput instrumentation and scale-up of the material production and coating process to pilot production. In the process, this project will develop tools and guidelines for manufacturing hierarchically-structured functional materials more generally.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Poor air quality has serious public health consequences and has been topping the headlines due to problems caused by wildfires and the COVID-19 pandemic. The problem touches everyone, everywhere, and cannot be escaped by staying indoors. According to the US EPA, indoor air quality (IAQ) is often two to five times worse than outdoor air, which is especially alarming since we spend ~90% of our time indoors. Indoor air has a complex composition consisting of particulate matter (PM), volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and airborne pathogens. Sub-micron particles represent a particular concern since they are ubiquitous in the indoor environment and have serious adverse health effects. Current solutions for indoor air purification rely mainly on ventilation with outdoor air and installation of filters into Heating Ventilation and Air Conditioning (HVAC) systems. Ventilation drives building energy use and cost while outdoor air is an increasingly unreliable source of clean air due to urban air pollution and the rise of climate change related wildfires. Furthermore, typical HVAC filters are inefficient for the removal of sub-micron PM, especially for smoke particles, which are < 300 nm. 

Metalmark validated a path toward scaling up the production of a nanostructured, bioinspired catalytic material, utilizing a raspberry inverse opal templating approach under an NSF SBIR Phase I project. This novel material offers the potential for catalytically cleaning indoor air, specifically targeting VOCs and pathogens. The purpose of the subsequent NSF SBIR Phase II project was to develop and scale up the material production and the associated application-specific coating processes to the relevant pilot levels to support their incorporation into final embodiments toward commercial product(s). During the project, we addressed the following technical challenges: 1) development of catalytic materials for application-specified functions; 2) development of coating processes and testing of coated substrates; 3) production of representative product prototypes by partners based on scaled-up processes; and 4) prototypical system build and testing with customers. 

The key achievements of this NSF Phase II project include: 

  • Scale-up of a new cost-effective and environmentally sustainable materials platform. 
  • Development of large-scale industrial coating processes of filter media utilizing the new materials platform. 
  • Fabrication of Metalmark coated pleated HVAC filters to show similar patterns as those observed in coated filter media. 
  • Third-party laboratory testing, indicating enhanced filtration efficiency against wildfire smoke plus additional benefits such as VOC sorption. 
  • Engineering of air cleaner units based on Metalmark’s patented technology and validation of the air cleaning capabilities of the design through a successful customer pilot demonstrating significant improvement of IAQ. 

 The R&D funded by the NSF under this Phase II contract has been critical for bringing Metalmark’s technology readiness level to TRL 8 in terms of product, scale, and customer validation.
